snippet: Robert Hannigan, director of Britain’s electronic eavesdropping agency, said young foreign jihadists who had grown up on the Internet had benefited from leaks by Edward J. Snowden.
abstract: Robert Hannigan, newly appointed director of Britain's electronic intelligence agency, castigates American internet companies for inadvertently providing terrorists with communication networks, and charges them to strike a better balance between privacy and security; comments are most virulent amid campaign by intelligence community against pressure to rein in their digital surveillance.

byline.original: By ALAN COWELL and MARK SCOTT
byline.contributor: Alan Cowell reported from London, and Mark Scott from Dublin. Reporting was contributed by Brian Chen, Vindu Goel and Nicole Perlroth from San Francisco; Katrin Bennhold from London; David E. Sanger from Washington; and Nick Wingfield from Seattle.

lead_paragraph: Robert Hannigan, director of Britain’s electronic eavesdropping agency, said young foreign jihadists who had grown up on the Internet had benefited from leaks by Edward J. Snowden.

headline.main: Top British Spy Warns of Terrorists’ Use of Social Media
headline.print_headline: Top British Spy Warns of Terrorists’ Use of Social Media
